section.title: Past Perfect
section.sectiontitle: Use the Past Perfect to talk about an action that happened before another action in the past. Make the Past Perfect with had + past participle.
section.text1: I went to France. It was my second time there.
section.text2: We listened to the CD for the first time.
section.text2a: We hadn't heard the CD before.
section.sectiontitle2: We often use the Past Perfect with the Past Simple, to make the order of actions clear.
section.text3: I left the party. She arrived.
section.text3a: When she arrived, I had already left the party.
section.text4: She lost her passport. She went to the Embassy.
section.text4a: She went to the Embassy because she had lost her passport.

section.title: Past Perfect
section.sectiontitle: We don't use the Past Perfect when the sequence of events is clear. We use the Past Simple.
section.text1: I got up. I had breakfast.
section.text1a: I got up and had breakfast.
section.text2: She won the lottery. She bought a new house.
section.text2a: She won the lottery and bought a new house.
section.sectiontitle2: The Past Perfect uses many of the same expressions as the Present Perfect (since, for, already).
section.text3: I saw Tom. It was the first time for six months.
section.text3a: I hadn't seen Tom since April.
section.text4: I spoke to Pete about the problem. I didn't have to reply to his email.
section.text4a: I didn't have to reply to Pete's email because I had already spoken to him.
